org.bm.blaise.scribo.parser
Interface SemanticNode

All Superinterfaces:
javax.swing.tree.TreeNode
All Known Subinterfaces:
SemanticArgumentNode
public interface SemanticNode
extends javax.swing.tree.TreeNode

Represents the semantic tree which can be used to actually calculate values. The primary method retrieves the value of the tree, assuming it can be calculated, as a class of type getValueType(). Secondary methods allow for retrieving all variables within the tree and returning the types of the immediate children of the node (called parameters).

To be completely precise:

  • The value of a node is the object that the node returns, possibly a numeric or boolean value or a string, or anything really.
  • The parameters of a node are the children of the TreeNode interface or the "subnodes"; the parameter types are the class types that are expected of the arguments.
  • Finally, the variables are the list of nodes in the tree with unknown values, identified by names and returned as a table.

Author:
Elisha Peterson

Method Detail

getParameterTypes

java.lang.Class[] getParameterTypes()
Returns array describing the class types of arguments of the node.

Returns:
an array of classes, in the same order as the child nodes at the argument; if there are no arguments and the node is a "function", should return an empty array; if the node is a leaf, e.g. a constant or a variable, should return a 0-length array.

getValueType

java.lang.Class getValueType()
Returns the object type of the return value as a class.

Returns:
class type of the object (should be the same or compatible with the type parameter)

getValue

java.lang.Object getValue()
                          throws SemanticTreeEvaluationException
Computes and returns the value of the node. Individual nodes representing variables are responsible for keeping track of their own values.

Returns:
value of this node, as an object of type specified by getReturnType()
Throws:
SemanticTreeEvaluationException - if the value cannot be determined (might happen if variables in the tree are undefined)

assignVariables

void assignVariables(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> valueTable)
Assigns values to all variables within the tree.

Parameters:
valueTable - the values as a map

getVariables

java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Class> getVariables()
Retrieve all unknown variables within the tree, returning them as a map associating the unknown variable name with its underlying class. This will generally be found by recursive introspection of subnodes.

Returns:
a map associating unknowns with their classes
